race.name: Total Tomahawk Terrain
race.tagline: Northern Wisconsin Northwoods gravel in Tomahawk.

climate.description: Variable summer conditions with potential for heat or rain.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through northern Wisconsin Northwoods. Rolling terrain with moderate elevation.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Small grassroots Wisconsin event. Affordable but very limited infrastructure and field.

biased_opinion.summary: Total Tomahawk Terrain is a small grassroots gravel race in remote northern Wisconsin. Tomahawk is tiny, amenities are basic, and the field is small. It's an honest local event with rolling Northwoods terrain and affordable pricing, but it's not trying to be more than a regional ride for Wisconsin cyclists.
weaknesses: Tiny field with no competitive depth
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A small local gravel race in remote Wisconsin. Perfect for locals who want an affordable weekend ride in the Northwoods. Not worth traveling far for unless you're combining with Wisconsin vacation.

final_verdict.one_liner: Small grassroots Wisconsin Northwoods ride with modest ambitions.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Only if you're in Wisconsin and want an affordable, low-key gravel ride in the Northwoods. Not worth traveling far for.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Wisconsin events: Chequamegon, Driftless Gravel. For similar grassroots vibes: other regional Midwest events.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Limited lodging in Tomahawk. Book early or look for nearby towns.
logistics.food: Small town with basic dining. Stock up beforehand.

history.origin_story: Grassroots gravel event in northern Wisconsin.

course_description.character: Rolling Northwoods gravel through forest and rural areas.
course_description.signature_challenge: Rolling Northwoods terrain and Wisconsin summer weather.

non_negotiables.why: Basic support means managing your own nutrition and mechanicals.

topics.execution: Race day tactics for grassroots events

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 62 miles of northern Wisconsin Northwoods gravel.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Small grassroots event in remote Tomahawk.

logistics.explanation: SARA Park provides camping, showers, and beach access, but the course is unmarked and riders navigate with paper cue sheets or GPS files. Chris Schotz serves as the sole organizer for this free ride with minimal infrastructure details available.

length.explanation: The TTT 103 offers a proper century-length challenge with resupply in Tripoli at mile 77 and lunch available in Ogema at mile 52. The Willow 63 requires complete self-support with no resupply points along its route. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: The course features 74% gravel through Lincoln, Taylor, and Oneida County Forests with numerous bridges over waterways. Rail-to-trails sections on Mountain-Bay, Hiawatha, and Wiouwash Trails contain many boardwalks rather than challenging technical terrain. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The signature climb reaches Timm's Hill at mile 60, Wisconsin's highest point at 1,951 feet. The 3,000 feet of total elevation gain over the course distance provides moderate climbing without mountain-level challenges. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 76°F and lows of 58°F, with a 53% chance of rain on any given day. June conditions in northern Wisconsin present variable weather possibilities, but no historical race weather data is available from the research. The event had a hiatus in 2020-2021, limiting weather pattern documentation. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Timm's Hill at 1,951 feet represents Wisconsin's highest elevation, which poses zero altitude concerns. The course runs through northern Wisconsin forests at modest elevations throughout. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Riders navigate unmarked routes through remote areas including Knox Mills Ghost Town at mile 68 and Gobler Lake State Natural Area. Self-supported sections require preparation with "whatever you can buy in Tripoli and the Windmill."

prestige.explanation: IRONBULL created this "old school free gravel bike ride" during the pandemic and recognized its value as a no-entry-fee event. It remains a grassroots Wisconsin ride without professional field or media coverage.

race_quality.explanation: Shane Hitz notes that "visitors often marvel at the quality of gravel riding we have in Central Wisconsin." However, the unmarked course and minimal support infrastructure keep this as a basic self-supported adventure.

experience.explanation: The route includes an ice cream shop stop at the Windmill on Lake Nokomis before riders spin down the bike path back to SARA Park. Post-ride amenities include park showers, beach access, and camping facilities.

community.explanation: IRONBULL, a 501(c)(3) organization, maintains the free format to welcome beginners - two-thirds of riders in 2020 completed their first gravel ride. The 7th edition adds shorter routes specifically to encourage new gravel riders.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 100-250 riders, the event actively courts beginners with multiple shorter route options and focuses on accessibility over competition. No past winners or competitive talent depth is documented in the available research. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Zero entry fee for 103 miles of Wisconsin forest gravel through three county forests makes this exceptional value. IRONBULL's 501(c)(3) status enables the free format that eliminates financial barriers to participation.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-90. Free entry eliminates the primary race expense, with SARA Park camping providing affordable lodging. Riders only pay for travel costs and whatever food they purchase in Tripoli during the resupply stop. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

citations.label: silentsportsmagazine.com: Ironbull Brings More Free Gravel Riding To North Central ...

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
